LETTER OF TRANSMITTAL His Excellency, Samuel R. McKelvie, Governor of Nebraska. Sir :Complying with the law governing the Board of Education haviag control of the Nebraska State Normal Schools, we herewith transmit to you the biennial report and statement of expenditures made by this Board from December i, 1918, to December 1, 1920. All original vouchers are on file with the auditor of public accounts and duplicates are on file in the office of the Board of Education. Respectfully submitted, H. E. REISCHE. Secretary

CHADRON STATE NORMAL SCHOOL 9 CHADRON STATE NORMAL SCHOOL Chadron, Nebraska, December I, 1920. To Th* Honorable Board of Education of the State Normal Schools : Gentlemen : 1 hereby submit a report of the condition of the Chadron State Normal School for the past biennium and some suggested improve - ments for the next biennium. NEW BUILDINGS The new gymnasium will be completed about February 1. This building would be a credit to any school in the state, and we now will be able to emphasize the physical phase of education, as well as the mental. The west wing of the main building should be extended the fifty feet in accordance with the original plan, which will enable us to enlarge our commercial department, provide an art and biology de - partment, and to house the library in a fire-proof building. We should have a dormitory large enough to accommodate all the girls who attend from out of town. This would also enable us to turn the present dormitory over to the boys. It is imperative that the young people who come here receive careful supervision, and this is possible only when they are housed in a dormitory, with someone in direct charge of them. Since the erection of the gymnasium, it will be necessary to enlarge the power house. It is now equipped with only two boilers, and two more at least should be added, which will give us a reserve of one in case any become incapacitated. By enlarging this building, provision will also be made for a larger supply of coal. NEW DEPARTMENTS In order to put our school on a par with the other normals of the state, it will be necessary the next biennium to provide for an art and a biology department. These have been neglected in the past, because of lack of space, but it is my desire to place more stress on this work in the future than we have in the past. Chadron, Nebraska ROBERT I. ELLIOTT, Pre.ident

STATE BOARD OF EDUCATION 10 ATTENDANCE Our attendance has been gradually increasing, although during the war it was not so noticeable. We hope to do more advertising in the future, and attract the young people in this section, who have not heretofore seen the importance of an education, and the advantages of a state normal. CAMPUS A landscape gardener has been employed and at the present time s plotting the campus. According to his statement this is one of the - reatest opportunities for campus development with which he has ome in contact. He is to plot the entire campus, and to attend to he planting of the trees and shrubbery himself this spring. I trust othing will interfere to retard this work, as I feel it if one of the most important single things to be done. ATHLETICS AND SCHOOL PAPER For i hi- past two years we have been developing an excellent foot - ball team, and this year it was even better than last. We hope to make this a permanent feature in the school. During the war athletics of any kind was practically impossible. tThis year, the school inaugurated a publication, issued weekly, is is appreciated by both the student body and the alumni, and going to add materially to the interest in the school. ASSEMBLY ROOM As soon as the west wing of the main building is completed it is loped an assembly room can be made of the present library. This will enable us to supervise all students below the junior and senior years, and is necessary in order that the young folks may make the greatest advancement. ENROLLMENT The enrollment for the school year 1918-19 was 599, counting none twice and including the model high school. Counting student twice who registered for consecutive semesters, the enrollment wa 752, including the model high school. For the school year 1919-20 the enrollment was 640 counting none twice and including the mode high school. Counting students twice who registered for consecu live semesters, the enrollment was 898 including the model hig! school

CHADRON STATE NORMAL SCHOOL 11 It will be noticed that there was a material increase the second year, and indications point to a still larger enrollment the coming biennium. Respectfully submitted, ROBERT T. ELLIOTT President CHADRON Financial Report for Biennium, Beginning December 1, 1918, and Ending December 1, 1920. KEARNEY STATE NORMAL SCHOOL 31 KEARNEY STATE NORMAL SCHOOL Kearney, Nebraska Kearney, Nebraska, December 1, 1920. The State Board of Education of Normal Schools The Nebraska State Normal School at Kearney has attempted during the past two years to meet the demands made upon it by the State of Nebraska. In some cases, notably when those demands were for trained teachers, the institution has been absolutely unable to comply. Kor three years past the enrollment has steadily declined. There are so many contributing causes at this condition that it is not possible to enter into its discussion here, as nothing in the way of conduct of the school can be charged with the falling off. At present tin- tendency is for the enrollment to increase, as will be observed by the report appended concerning ENROLLMENT Enrollment, 1918-19 4&J Enrollment. 1918-19, correspondence students.. Enrollment, Summer Term. 1910 7^ 85 • i.4«" Enrollment, 1919-20 4-^4 Enrollment, correspondence students 122 Enrollment. Study Center students 40 Enrollment. Summer Term, 1920 1,087 1 .67.? Enrollment. 19-io, to December 1 370 Enrollment. Correspondence students 129 Enrollment. Study Center students 173 681 GEORGE E. MARTIN, President Gentlemen :

32 Number of Elementary Certificates granted since Dec. i, 1918 12 Number of Junior Certificates granted since Dec. 1, 1918 60 Number of Diplomas granted since Dec. 1, 1918 166 Number of A. B. Degrees granted since Dec. 1. 1918 29 Number of Advanced Rural Certificates granted since Dec. 1, 1918 10 Number of Elementary Rural Certfs. granted since Dec. 1, 1918 41 3i8 EXTENSION WORK There has been an earnest effort on the part of this institution o carry its services to the people through two important channels. )ne of these is through correspondence work, where the student does lot come in direct contact with the Institution but acquires his train - ng, so far as possible, through the means of themes written for omment and correction and in following the outlines of courses of eading. The other means is that of study centers. Wherever ten people will select some subject or subjects they wish to study, the nstitution has sent an instructor who takes charge of the class on r riday evenings or Saturdays, and attempts to carry the atmosphere of the normal school to the local center. The first named means. as will be observed from the increase above, has shown a steady ncrease. Ere long a special faculty will have to be appointed for uch work. The last named means has been especially popular dur - ng the fall months just passed. Twenty-five such centers are now in operation in the towns and villages surrounding Kearney. LIBRARY For the successful carrying on of the work outlined above, as well as that of the regular school activities, numerous additions and mprovements have been made in the library here, in the way of books and decorations of the walls. The number of volumes at present is 23,972. This, it will be noted, is an increase of 7,883 volumes since he last biennial report. GYMNASIUM The work in the splendidly equipped gymnasium, erected in 1916. has been enhanced by the addition to the faculty of a physical di - rector for men and one for women. Each of these teachers regularly is carrying work in physical training for the students of the institu - tion. Much good is resulting therefrom. During the present year a

KEARNEY STATE NORMAL SCHOOL 33 School Nurse has been added, whose services are of practical value to those carrying on the work just mentioned. It is the intention to make her work largely preventive, rather than curative, in her min - istrations to students. AFFILIATED RURAL SCHOOLS The work of the Rural School Department has been considerably broadened by the affiliation of several rural schools in the immed - iate vicinity. At present, affiliation has been effected between this institution and the Victor School, District No. 88, the Glenwood School. District No. 14, the Riverdale School, District No. 15, and the Collins School. Kearney City District. The head of the ruarl school department in the institution exercises supervisory powers over the schools named above, and the students of his department do practice teaching in them. The result is of benefit to the normal school and 10 the affiliated district. PERMANENT IMPROVEMENTS At the beginning of this biennium the State was in possession of an experimental farm of eighteen acres situated three miles south - west of the main building of this institution. In 1919 it became ap - parent that the land lying adjacent to the campus on the west and north would be purchased by home builders and a number of dwell - ings be placed quite near the normal school campus. Since the land was for sale, it seemed wise to the Normal School Board of Educa - tion to secure this land and add it to the campus. A trade was ef - fected by means of which the eighteen acre experimental farm was transferred to the hitherto owner of the land adjacent to the campus. and the latter became the property of the State and is now a perma - nent asset of the State Normal School at Kearney. This extended the campus about thirty-one acres and gives the campus an area of approximately fifty acres at the present time. It would be greatly wise if the State could see fit to purchase additional land to the east of the present plant to the extent of about one block. This would give room for an administration building, which is one of the things that will be needful within a comparatively few years. The advance in price of building property makes it evi - dent that such a thing should be consummated at the earliest pos - sible moment. OTHER NEEDS OF THE SCHOOL The need for a Training School Building in this institution is so obvious and has been mentioned in so many previous reports that

STATE BOARD OF EDUCATION 34 it is not wise to enlarge upon it here. It will suffice la my that the need is no less urgent than hitherto. The most imminent need is that of suitable dormitory facilities to house the students. This need became a crying one during the past year. During the Summer Term of 1920 it was well-night impossible to accommodate alt students. A commodious, modern building, capable of caring for at feast two hundred students, should be erected during the next bienniutn. 54 PERU STATE NORMAL SCHOOL Peru, Nebraska E. L. ROUSE, President Peru, Nebraska, December 2, 1920. To the Nebraska State Board of Education : Gentlemen : I am pleased to submit herewith the biennial report of the fern State Normal School. This report includes a detailed statement of the receipts and expenditures for the biennium up to December 1, 1920. I am taking the liberty of submitting an estimate of the funds needed for this institution for the next biennium. There is set forth a brief outline of the essential needs of the institution. If they arc to do their part in meeting the present emergency in education it seems to me the slogan for the State Normal Schools should be, "A trained teacher for each boy and girl in Nebraska." You will find a detailed statement of the attendance by years. This smaller attendance is common to all Normal Schools of tin- United States. There is need for a vigorous campaign to awaken the public to the startling shortage of trained teachers and to enlis' their interest in recruiting students for the Normal Schools. BUILDINGS AND MATERIAL EQUIPMENT Improvements During This Biennium Mt. Vernon Hall, the girls' dormitory, has been greatly improved. The building has been replastered throughout, new floors laid, walls inted, and woodwork revarnished. The bathrooms have been fitted with the most up-to-date equipment, including shower baths. The dining room and kitchen in connection with the dormitory have been completely remodeled. We have taken over the boarding department and are conducting it as a state institution. It is proving highly satisfactory. We have constructed during the biennium a coal storage building. This re-enforced concrete structure was built by our own force at a very limited expense, when the annual saving it insures is considered. It permits us to store during the summer time 1500 tons of coal. We have just completed the paving of a 24-foot road across the

PERU STATE NORMAL SCHOOL 55 campus with a spur to the coal storage plant. This was done at ;i cost of $20,000. One needs only to see the improvement to know thai it was money well invested. Needs for tbe Coining Biennium The most imperative need of the institution is a new Science building. Tbe old frame structure which we have been compelled to use for this important department is entirely inadequate. A new modern fireproof building should be constructed at once. It would probably cost $125,000. The old Normal Hall, which has stood since the organization of the school, is practically useless in its present condition. The south wing should be wrecked. There should be an appropriation to re - model and make modern in every way the north wing. It could then he used for the Music Department, Estimated cost $35,000. There seems to be no reasonable way to correct the poor accous - lics of our Auditorium. I suggest that the Auditorium be converted into a gymnasium and that the present basement gymnasium be remodeled so as to provide a swimming pobl and adequate locke 1 rooms. Estimated cost $25,000. PROFESSIONAL ATTAINMENTS During the biennium the school has employed a trained nurse as a regular faculty member. We have rented a suite of rooms which is known as the school infirmary. Each year every pupil in the train - ing school is given a thorough physical examination, and recom - mendations are made to parents. The health of all students is care - fully considered. We are certain that this department keeps our student body much more efficient and is saving hundreds of dollars each year for the student body. During the biennium we have greatly increased our extension woi k through study centers and correspondence courses. For the school year 1919-20 we enrolled 142 students in study centers and 42 in correspondence courses. The advantages of a Field Director are very apparent. From practically every community he visited, he brought recruits. The in - creased enrollment of men is due largely to his work. By keeping in direct touch with the work of our graduates, he is able to bring back many valuable suggestions for not only the training school but the various departments. There has been a steady increase in the enrollment for the Senior College work. During the biennium more than one hundred students have been enrolled in this department. We have granted 23 A. B. Degrees this biennium. It seems to me the time has come when the Normal Schools should be recognized as Teachers' Col-

56 leges. This recognition is given the Normal Schools of Iowa, Colo- rado, Missouri, and many other states. NEEDS FOR THE COMING BIENNIUM The following estimates represent the minimum needs for the biennium beginning April I, 1921 : 1. Salaries and Wages : Administration, salaries of president and office force $ 40,282 Faculty 183,342 Assistants 7.300 Employees 26,576 2. Administrative expenses, including postage, telegraph and telephone, freight, express, drayage, water, printing, ad - vertising 15,000 3. Supplies, office supplies, fuel, educational supplies 35,000 4. Material : Buildings and grounds, machinery, power plants, trucks 8,500 r Lands and Buildings, original construction, additions and improvements 200,000 t Equipment, office furniture, fixtures, and equipment, labo - ratory, books, magazines, and maps 7,500 Total maintenance $523,500 ENROLLMENT Regular Summer Regular Summer Year School Year School 1918-19 1919 1919-20 1920 Collegiate students in resident attendance 263 416 221 535 Secondary students in resident attendance 186 121 95 147 Correspondence students 36 37 42 Study center students . 142 Total 485 574 500 682 Training school, kindergarten to tenth grade, inclusive 181 109 176 82 Affiliated rural school 37 42 Grand Total 703 683 718 764 t^tion of the Appropriations Funds of the Peru State Normal School, Peru, Nebraska, December 1, 1920. WAYNE STATE NORMAL SCHOOL 79 I WAYNE STATE NORMAL SCHOO Wayne. Nebraska, December i. iq:s> To tin Sum- Board of Education of Normal Schools i I am pleased to submit herewith the- biennial report of the State Mormal School. This includes a detailed report of the expenditures during the past two years and suggestions as to the needs of the school for the ensuing biennrum. FACULTY This institution is very fortunate in haying a strong faculty. For the most part the same professors are at the heads of depart - ments as were placed in charm' more than ten years ago when the school was organized. They have grown with the institution. Their fine spirit of co-operation in all the general activities of the school has contributed materially to the wellbeing of the institution. When members of our alumni association visit the institution and find their old instructors in their accustomed places it tends to center interests in the institution which could not obtain under any other condition. PERMANENT IMPROVEMENTS Daring the past two years no building has been attempted. Quite an amount of grading, however, has been done on the enlarged campus and the excavating for an artificial lake has been practically completed. This lake when cemented and filled will make an at - tractive feature in the landscape scheme of the campus. But little has been done in the way of laying out permanent drives for tin reason that it has been impossible to secure material for their con - struction. An electric light plant lias been installed and from now on tin - institution will be able to produce its own current at a fraction of :he cost heretofore paid. The generators an- driven by steam tur - bines: the exhaust from the turbines is all used in heating the water Wayne, Nebraska U. S. CONN, President Gentlemen

80 in the general hot water system. So there is no loss of steam and apparently no increase in the amount of coal consumed. During the past year the street leading from the business part 01" town to the Xnrinal lias been paved. This is a much needed im - provement and is of much advantage to the school. The paving ex - ends entirely along the west side of the campus and one block along he south side. The expense to the State for this imprvement will be about $12,000. NEEDED IMPROVEMENTS k During the ensuing btennram some additional grading should In ne. The athletic field should be completed and permanent drives ould be laid out and paved. DORMITORY The most urgent need of the institution is a modern dormitory n view of the fad that those who teach school, for the most part, ome from homes of moderate means, their expenses must be re- Inced tq the minimum in order to enable them to secure the neces - ary preparation for teaching. Experience has shown that dormitory ccommodations of the most approved kind can be provided at an xpense of not to exceed one dollar per week for each student, whilr accommodations of a similar kind in private homes cost from two o three dollars. Such a difference is very marked in the total yearly expense of the student. In view of the fact that those who attend the State Normal School are preparing to teach and in this way will reimburse ihe commonwealth for the money expended, it seems <.• \ i dent that the state may make no better use of some of its funds Em to build modern housing facilities for those who are preparing teach its youth. When viewed from the standpoint of discipline, alth of students, progress in the work, and social well being, to say nothing of the reduced expense, the dormitory is very desirable. A building should l>e erected ;it the earliest possible date which will provide for the comfortable housing of from two hundred to twi hundred fiftj young women. The housing- facilities which are now provided hj 1I1, school together with all available housing facilities <>f tin- town are i:c\ni to the utmost during certain parts of the ;t year and unlen> more adequate quarters nrr provided the growth rhe school will b« bronchi to ;\ standstill. Such a dormitory as wil inert th< needs of iln school will cost from $150,000 to $200,000. Othi general improvements of tin grounds which should not longer be .1 such as drives, grading, ornamentation, landscaping and im- provement of athletic field, will cost at least $40,000.

WAYNE STATE NORMAL SCHOOL 81 GENERAL EXPENSES It will be noted that the general expenses of the institution for maintenance- have gradually increased during the last biennium. This increased expense, however, is only in keeping with increased ex - penses in all other lines. One or two specific instances may suffice to explain this necessary outlay of public funds. Five years ago the coal delivered at the heating plant cost $4.85 a ton ; the same coal now delivered costs $10.60 a ton. The night fireman five years ago was employed at $45.00 a month ; he now receives $105 a month. Other items of expense, while possibly not increased in the same ratio, are very much more than formerly. ELEMENTARY RURAL DEPARTMENT The elementary rural department is performing an important service. It covers the two years immediately following the com - pletion of the eighth grade. For the most part those who take this work are mature students who have completed the work of the country school. These young people understand rural conditions and have no difficulty in organizing the work of the rural school. County superintendents who have our elementary rural students teaching for them are enthusiastic about the work which is being done. No claim is made that such teachers are professional. The attempt in the two years is to give some definite notion about or - ganization and management and a good knowledge of the subjects to be taught in a country school. Before the elementary rural course was established a majority of the mature students from rural districts, remained in school an average of one semester; now all of those who complete the work are enrolled at least two years. I feel that it will be a long time under present conditions before we can expect rural teachers to have the same scholastic attainments as those who teach in the graded school. Social, financial and general living conditions are not such in the country as to be an inducement to the graduates from the advanced course to choose country schools rather than graded schools. The elementary rural course which seeks to give two yta^s of intensive training is the most valuable thing which state normal schools are doing in the solution of the rural school problem. ATTENDANCE RECORD The annual enrollment for the school has increased in ten years from 539 to 1062 and the number of graduates from the advanced course from three to 79. The number receiving professional life cer-

82 STATE BOARD OF EDUCATION tificates during the year 1919 was 51 ; in 1920 it was 69. In 1930. twenty-nine received the elementary rural certificate. Respectfully submitted. U. S. CONN.
